originalTitle: Bid launched to extend Zimbabwe president's term in office
title: News from Zimbabwe: A Big Job for Our President!
content:
Hello Young Explorers!

Hello, my amazing friends! I'm your Kid-Friendly News Reporter for Africa, and I'm so excited to share some important news from a wonderful country called Zimbabwe. Zimbabwe is in Southern Africa, a beautiful land with lots of friendly people, incredible wildlife like elephants and giraffes, and bright sunny days. Today, we're going to talk about something important happening with their leader, President Mnangagwa. Don't worry, we'll keep it super simple, just like a story!

Meet President Mnangagwa and Zimbabwe!

Every country has a special leader, kind of like how your classroom has a teacher, or a football team has a captain. For Zimbabwe, that special leader is President Mnangagwa. He has a very big and important job. He helps make sure everything in the country runs smoothly, that kids can go to school, and that people have food and homes. Imagine you are the leader of your whole family or your street – that’s a bit like what a president does, but for a whole country! Zimbabwe is a fantastic country, full of vibrant culture and warm smiles. It's a place where many different animals roam free, and where people work hard to make their country grow strong. President Mnangagwa is chosen by the people to guide Zimbabwe.

What Does a President Do?

So, what does a president actually do all day? Well, it's a very busy job! A president helps decide how schools will be, how roads will be built, and how to keep everyone safe. They talk to other leaders from different countries too, to make friends and help Zimbabwe grow. It’s like being the head chef in a giant kitchen, making sure all the ingredients are there and everyone gets a good meal. President Mnangagwa works very hard for the people of Zimbabwe. His job is to look after the country and help everyone have a good life. He listens to people and tries to make the best decisions for everyone, young and old.

Did you know? The word "president" comes from an old word that means "to sit before," like someone who sits in charge of a meeting!

The President's Time Limit

Now, here's an interesting part. In many countries, like Zimbabwe, a president gets a special amount of time to do their big job. It’s like when you play a game and you know how many rounds you have, or how long the game will last. For President Mnangagwa, his time, or his "term," is set to end in the year 2028. That’s still a few years away! This rule, about how long a president can stay, is very important. It's part of the country's big rule book, called the Constitution, which tells everyone how things should work. This rule book makes sure that different people get a chance to be the leader and bring new ideas. It's like having turns in a game – everyone gets a chance to play! Having a time limit helps keep things fair and gives the people a chance to choose again later.

Why Do We Have Rules?

Think about your school or your home. You have rules, right? Like, "no running in the corridors," or "tidy up your toys." Rules help everyone know what to do, keep things safe, and make sure everyone is treated fairly. Well, countries have rules too, called "laws." These laws are super important because they help keep the whole country running smoothly and fairly. They tell us how we choose our leaders, how long they can lead, and what they can and cannot do. These rules are usually made by many different people together, not just one person, to make sure they are good for everyone. They are like the instructions for how a country should work.

Did you know? The oldest set of laws we know about was written over 3,700 years ago! It was called the Code of Hammurabi!

A New Idea for the Rules

Here's where the news comes in! Right now, there’s an idea, like a suggestion, that some people are talking about. This idea is to change the rule about how long President Mnangagwa can be the leader. Instead of his time ending in 2028, this new idea would let him stay for a longer time. It’s like if you’re playing a game, and someone says, "Let's change the rules so I can play for more rounds!" This idea is still just an idea, or a "bill." It means it needs to be talked about a lot and voted on by many people before it can become a real rule, or a "law." It’s a very big discussion for Zimbabwe.

Why Are Clear Rules Good?

Having clear rules, especially about how long leaders stay in power, is really important for a country. It helps everyone trust the system. If rules can be changed too easily, it might make some people happy and others worried. Imagine playing hide-and-seek, and someone suddenly says, "The seeker can count to 5 instead of 10!" It changes the game. When a president has a clear end date, it helps everyone prepare for a new election, where people can choose their next leader. It helps keep the country strong and democratic, which means the people have a say in who leads them. Clear rules are like the sturdy foundations of a house – they keep everything strong and safe.

What Happens Next?

So, what happens with this idea? Well, this "bill" or new rule idea will be discussed by many smart people in Zimbabwe. They will talk about if it's a good idea, if it will help the country, and if it's fair. They will listen to what many people think. It's not a quick decision, it takes time and lots of talking. Just like when your family discusses a big decision, like where to go for a holiday, everyone needs to think about it carefully. This process helps make sure that any new rule is thought through very well. There will be lots of discussions, and many voices will be heard.

Did you know? When people vote for a president, they usually put a mark next to their chosen person's name on a piece of paper, and these are then counted!

Why This Matters to You!

Even though you are young, this news is important for you too! Why? Because the leaders of a country make decisions that affect everyone, including kids! They decide about schools, hospitals, and parks – all the things that help you grow up happy and healthy. Knowing how leaders are chosen and how rules work helps you understand your country better. It helps you see how important it is for everyone to have a say and for rules to be fair. As you grow older, you will also get to have your say by voting! So, paying attention to news like this helps you learn about how the world works and how you can be a good citizen in the future. It’s all part of learning about your amazing continent, Africa!
summary: Some people in Zimbabwe want to change the rules so President Mnangagwa, who is the country's leader, can stay in his job for longer than his current time, which is set to end in 2028.
whyMatters: This matters because rules about how long a leader can stay are very important for a country to be fair and for everyone to have a chance to choose their leaders. Changing rules about leaders can affect how the country is run and the future for all its people, including kids.

originalTitle: African artefacts looted by British to be returned
title: Amazing News! Our Special Old Treasures Are Coming Home!
content:
Hello, My Friends! Big News from Africa!

Hello, my wonderful friends! Your friendly African news reporter is here with super exciting news! Get ready to clap your hands and cheer, because something truly special is happening right here in our amazing home, Africa. Today, we have a story that will make your heart sing! It's about very old and very important things that are coming back home to us. Imagine your favourite toy going on a super long trip, and then finally, after many, many years, it comes back to you! That’s how special this news is. We are talking about beautiful art and cool objects that belong to Africa, specifically to a wonderful country called Nigeria. They are finally, truly, really coming back! This is big news for everyone, especially for the children who will get to see them.

What Are These Special Things?

So, what are these special things we are talking about? They are called "artefacts" (say: AR-te-facks). But that's a big word! Let's call them "special old treasures" or "amazing African art." These treasures are not just any old things. They are very old statues, beautiful carvings made of wood or metal, and many other pretty objects. Each one tells a story about the people who made them a very, very long time ago. Imagine someone carved a lion's head or a person's face into wood or shiny metal. These are the kinds of amazing things we are talking about! They show how clever and artistic our ancestors were. Did you know? Some of these special old treasures from Nigeria are called 'Benin Bronzes'. They are not all made of bronze, some are made of ivory (which comes from elephant tusks) or wood, but they are all very famous for being so beautiful and detailed! These treasures are important because they are a big part of our history. They help us remember where we come from and what amazing things people in Africa have done for hundreds of years.

How Did They Go Away?

Now, you might be wondering, if they are so special and belong to us, how did they go away in the first place? Well, this is the sad part of the story, but it’s important to know. Many, many years ago, when your great-great-grandparents were probably just little children, some soldiers from a country far away called Britain came to Africa. They came to a place in Nigeria called Benin City. During a difficult time, these soldiers took many of these beautiful treasures without asking. It was not right, and it made many people very sad. Taking something that doesn't belong to you is called 'looting' or 'stealing'. Imagine someone coming into your house and taking your favourite toys without your permission. That's what happened, but with very precious art and history from Africa. Did you know? This happened so long ago, in the year 1897. That's more than 120 years ago! Think about how many birthdays you've had, then imagine 120 birthdays! So, for a very, very long time, these treasures have been away from their home. They have been in museums and art galleries in different countries, far, far away from Africa.

A Long, Long Time Ago...

Let’s talk a little more about "a long, long time ago." When we say the "late 19th Century," it means the years around 1897. In those days, there were no cell phones, no televisions, and cars looked very different. People wrote letters with pens and paper, and travelled by horse or on foot for many miles. Nigeria was a very important kingdom back then, especially Benin City. It was known for its amazing artists and craftsmen who made incredible things. They used their hands and special tools to create masterpieces. Did you know? The artists in Benin City were so good that their artwork was known all around the world, even back then! They were like superstar artists of their time! These treasures were not just pretty; they were often used in special ceremonies, or to show who was important, like the King of Benin. They had deep meaning for the people.

Where Were They Kept?

After they were taken, these special African treasures were moved to different places. Many of them ended up in big museums and art galleries in Britain and other countries in Europe. These museums are like very big houses where old and special things are kept so people can come and look at them. They are important places for learning. But even though people could see them in these museums, the treasures were far away from their true home. It's like a fish living in a beautiful aquarium, but wishing it was back in the big ocean where it truly belongs. For many, many years, people from Nigeria and other parts of Africa have been asking for these special things to be returned. They said, "These are our stories, our history, they belong here with us." Did you know? There are thousands of these special treasures that were taken from Benin City. Not just a few, but many, many thousands! It will take a long time for all of them to come back.

Coming Back Home!

And now, the happy news! After all those years, the time has come. Some of these very special treasures are officially, truly, really coming back home to Nigeria! This means that the people in Britain who were looking after them have agreed to send them back. They understand that these treasures are part of Nigeria's heart and soul. It’s a bit like finding a lost puppy and finally returning it to its happy owner! Everyone is so happy and excited for these treasures to be reunited with their home country. This is a big moment for Nigeria and for all of Africa. It shows that talking, understanding, and doing the right thing can bring about wonderful changes. Did you know? Many different museums and universities are working together to send these treasures home. It's a big team effort to make sure everything comes back safely.

Why Is This So Exciting?

Why is this news so exciting for us, especially for you, the children of Africa? Because these treasures are not just old objects; they are like storybooks without words. When you see these statues and carvings in a museum in Nigeria, you will be able to connect with your own history. You will see the amazing creativity of your ancestors. It helps us to feel proud of our rich African history and culture. It reminds us that Africa has always been a place of great art, wisdom, and strong people. Did you know? When these treasures come back, they will help tell the story of the ancient Kingdom of Benin even better. It's like adding missing pages back into a very important history book! They will be put in museums where everyone, especially kids like you, can visit and learn. It’s a chance to see history up close and personal!

What Will Happen Next?

So, what happens now that they are coming back? First, they will travel very carefully from Britain all the way back to Nigeria. It's a long journey, so they will be looked after very well. Once they arrive in Nigeria, they will be kept safely in special places, like a brand new museum being built just for them! Imagine a whole new museum filled with our returning treasures! Then, children from Nigeria and visitors from all over the world will be able to come and see them. You can look at the intricate details, imagine the artists who made them, and learn about their stories. This is just the beginning! Many people hope that even more African treasures that are still in museums far away will also come back home in the future. Did you know? There are plans to build a fantastic new museum in Benin City, Nigeria, to house many of these returning artefacts. It will be a place of learning and pride for generations to come!

Let's Learn About Our History!

This exciting news teaches us many things. It teaches us about fairness, about doing what is right, and about the importance of our history and culture. It shows us that our history, our art, and our stories are very important. They should be celebrated and kept safe in their own homes. So, next time you hear about these returning treasures, remember the amazing story of how they went away and how they are finally, happily, coming home to Africa. Let’s be proud of our African heritage and excited for all the learning and beauty these returning treasures will bring to Nigeria and to all of us! Did you know? Learning about history helps us understand the world better today and helps us make good choices for the future. So keep asking questions and keep learning, my friends!
summary: Beautiful and special old African art, called artefacts, that were taken from Nigeria a very long time ago by British soldiers, are now officially coming back home to Nigeria, making everyone very happy.
whyMatters: This is important because it means special art and history that belongs to Africa is finally coming back, so children and everyone can see it, learn from it, and feel proud of our rich African culture and past.

originalTitle: Pilot praised after crash-landing faulty Somali passenger plane on seashore
title: Pilot praised after crash-landing faulty Somali passenger plane on seashore
content: All 55 people on board survived after the plane failed to land on the runway near the shoreline.
